Grossman led in the tallying with
six field goals and two free throws
from the foul line for a total of

been playing bang-up basketball all

the need of his presence in such
games as Wednesday night's, as he

works. His superb passing accuracy adds a good bit of speed to
the Jay offense. Nevertheless, he
will be in the lineup Saturday afternoon when Loyola is met and much
will be expected of him.

The Homewood Playshop announces the presentation of three
modern German one-act plays. Rehearsals are in progress and the
plays will be on view to the public
on the evenings of March 3, 6, 7

von Hofmannsthal's "Death and the
Fool" and Frank Wedekind's "The
Tenor." Hofmannsthal's play will
be presented in German, the other
two in English. The production
will be directed by Professor Ernst
Feise of the German Department,
who has thus summarized the significance of these plays:

artistic and philosophic creations.
The war especially has taught us
that a new consciousness of human
solidarity is indispensable and that
the unlimited individualism, the result of the atomisation of our mechanized age, can only lead to disaster. But such an insight is prepared by the later impressionists, in
German drama in the works of
Schnitzler, von Hofmannsthal, and

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
The McGill Daily of Montreal
reveals in a recent issue the startling
information that the University's
founder and benefactor, James McGill owed his brewer fifteen
pounds for ale at the former's decease. The debt, continues the organ, was incurred in recompensing
his constituents for his election to
the legislature. The administrators
of the McGill estate later settled the
account for five pounds.
The knowledge that McGill feted
his boosters on mortgaged beer,
forces one to exclaim, "just like a
politician !"
The knowledge, however, that the
administrators settled a fifteen
pound bill for five pounds without
indicating what they had done with
the other ten gives birth to inferences that are too obvious and too
natural to warrant command in
connection with administerial practices.
Ranulph Kingsley, prominent
member of the New York College
Club declares in a dispatch to the
same publication that the college
club has "an ill effect on new graduates. New York, it appears, is
particularly pregnant with such organizations and year after year
hordes of graduates descend on the
club rooms for a jolly good time.
"As long as cash or credit lasts,"
opines Mr. Kingsley, "they live a
life that many European princes
would envy. Chatting on expensively decorated lounges, armchairs
and divans, sleeping in spotless bed
rooms, and swimming in limpid,
translucent pools, these men enjoy
luxuries that few others in much
higher realms ever experience.

The club should teach these
young men that all through life
they must pay their own way
The college man has always lived
on someone else; first on his parents, then on his college credit, and
then on his college club."
* * *
As far as we are able to perceive
the life depicted above is quite a
charming one and one not likely, as
may be observed, to be underestimated by college graduates. From
a logical standpoint, it does not
seem unusual for persons who undergo a parasitic existence for four
years to continue that existence in
post-graduation days. In fact it is
downright consistent. The evil,
therefore, is not entombed in the
graduate clubs, but in the collegiate
atmosphere itself.
Ergo, Let us abolish parasitic existences.
Ergo, Let us abolish students.
Ergo, eLt us abolish colleges.
Ergo, Amen.
* * *
A second and more meditative
suggestion has been generated
through the influence of the passage on the "envy of European
princes." The life of ease described
in the foregoing verily has been and
is envied by princes. But princes
not only envy this life but they actually achieve it by marrying moving picture actresses. Hence, with
such an undeveloped field open, it is
a wonder that college boys have not
taken possession of it previously.
Indeed the story of the man who
wanted to marry Greta Garbo for
her money takes on a new significance.

EDITORIALS
GOOD NEWS!!
President

T a recent meeting of the Board of Collegiate Studies,
A
Ames requested the Committee on Educational Methods and
Policies to make a thorough investigation of the undergraduate school

and to suggest improvements'wherever necessary. This committee is
now working in conjunction with some students to decide matters of
vital importance for the future of Johns Hopkins.
The significance of this step lies in the fact that it marks an entire
reversal of the attitude of the University authorities toward the undergraduate schools. Ever since the advent of the Goodnow Plan, Alma
Mater has been a step-mother to the undergraduates. In the first rush
of enthusiasm for a purely graduate school, the undergraduates, to put
it plainly, were somewhat neglected. Courses were cut out of the curriculum, five professors gave up their undergraduate classes, and an
increase in enrollment in the College was not urgently desired. We
believe that this old policy is dead, that a new era has started in which
the undergraduate schools will not only recover their former prestige,
but will surpass it. Perhaps we have been too harsh in writing of the
past, perhaps we attach too much importance to the present, perhaps
we are too optimistic as regards the future. Nevertheless, it seems to
us that the investigation now being conducted represents a change of
policy that will prove of great benefit. The essential point is not that
the committee may recommend great changes, it is that an effort is
being made to improve the undergraduate colleges by facing facts.

•

The problems being discussed range all the way from additions
to the curriculum to what may be done for activities. Perhaps the most
important problem is whether the University now offers sufficient
courses to enable each student to acquire a liberal education, and if
the answer is no (as we confidently expect it to be) what courses should
be added. We can suggest quite a few: Political Economy courses, such
as Accounting and Money and Banking should be instituted for men
in the College of Arts and Sciences; there is room for several English
courses, such as the modern novel, modern drama, and several courses
specializing in two or three authors to supplement the survey courses
now being given; in French a course in nineteenth and twentieth century literature would be well attended. These are a few suggestions for
new courses, but a much easier step could be made which would greatly
enrich the curriculum. That is to compel the high and mighty Business
Economics faculty to thiow open more of their courses to students in
other colleges and to abolish some of the pre-requisites in that school.
At present we are in a benign mood; we are at peace with the world;
so we cannot do this subject justice. But when our digestion fails,
when some other misfortune occurs to make us slightly bitter, we shall
then take up the question of the "splendid isolation" of the Business
School more fully.
The committee is also considering the question of advisers. The
system we have at present, whereby each instructor has several students
under his wing is far from satisfactory. Many of the instructors regard
the system as a nuisance and a time-waster for themselves. And justly
so. The faculty has been chosen with the view that they are men
qualified to teach their particular subject. It is no part of their duty to
guide bewildered freshmen through the wage of college. The office
of Assistant Dean should be created and he could be assisted by five
seniors each year. The advantages of this plan are two-fold. First, the
assistant would be a man who would be thoroughly acquainted with
the curriculum and the peculiarities of each course and, secondly, hc
would have the time and would be paid to advise so that each man
would be given careful consideration instead of being treated in a
haphazard fashion. It would be advantageous to have him assisted by
seniors as they would be men who had just recently taken the courses
in the College, and consequently would be able to explain to the
Assistant Dean any changes which the professors make in their courses

UTOPIA
By PAUL W. SPEAR
Another period of "Sturm and Drang" has passed and another set of examinations belongs to the past. The present marking system is making its last stand against reform. Well may we
sigh with relief that shortly undergraduates are no longer to be
slaves to a string of marks. But while the faculty was so busy reforming the marking system, it neglected the very important task
of reforming itself, the markers. Long have we undergraduates
pleaded for the establishment of equal standards among the various instructors in the college and yet our pleas remain unnoticed
and we have been forced to abide by the arbitrary set of standards
established by individual instructors. Will the new marking system relieve this difficulty to any extent? Obviously not, for every
member of the faculty still will have different ideas as to who
among his students may be classed as an honor student. Some
cynical and hard-hearted members of the faculty believe none of
us is worthy of being designated as better than satisfactory; others are too generous in granting honors to those of us who may
make a good impression by some chance performance which may
have been meaningless. A111 degrees of difference lie between these
two extremes and each student is compared with his fellows on a
different basis. The scholarship committee may think that numerical averages form a sound means for awarding honors, the Phi
Beta Kappa Society may award its key to men with the highest
average, but neither has a reliable source for its judgments.
Two men with equal ability who have done equal amounts of work
may under either the present or future system be classified in separate divisions as to their respective merits.
Again, I say, the faculty should adopt some agreement
among all its members so that a uniform system may result which
will take into account the varying difficulty of different subjects
and what may be reasonably expected from a conscientious student.
The trend indicated by the new marking system is the establishment of standards of scholarship among the undergraduates in
accord with those already existing in the graduate school. The
purpose of any marking system is to establish a basis on which
a student may judge the results of his own labor in comparison
with the rest of the student body. If his work is satisfactory it
will be so designated and if he is far better than average, he
will have the satisfaction of knowing this. But what good does
such a system accomplish? It will remove any attempts to judge
.and compare students by the actual percentage of given knowledge which they have learnt to appy-; but aside from this it is not
much of an improvement.
If the faculty is actually sincere in its desire to establish the
ideal system, then let there be no system at all. A complete abolition of any form of marking whatsoever is more highly desirable
than any possible system involving marks. A college student is supposedly a seeker of knowledge. The teacher is there to aid his students in acquiring this knowledge, and his should not be the duty
.of passing judgment. A man comes to college to equip himself for
life and only the future will tell whether he has been sucecssful.
The world in which he makes his living will be the real judge of
his accomplishments and ability. A true teacher is one whose superior knowledge equips him to become a source and radiating
.center of information. Coming to the teacher with a respect for
his knowledge and the desire to partake of it even as Aristotle
learnt from Plato, the student should be on a thoroughly friendly
basis with his teachers. As long as teachers are required to officially judge their pupils, no true feeling of friendship can arise
between the two. Once, however, the student knows that upon
himself alone rests the burden of accomplishment then will he regard his teachers in a purely unselfish light. There will be no need
to distinguish between handshaking and sincerity—the former
will have no purpose.
Of course, the plan will meet with objections. The average
college .student needs constant driving if he is to acquire knowledge. This plan however is not concerned with the average student, for Hopkins is endeavoring to avoid mediocrity. Raise entrance requirements and eliminate many of the undesirables who
,are wasting their time in college. Those who do get in and yet do
not work will cause no trouble, for the knowledge is there to be
absorbed by those who want it; while those who ignore it are
digging their own graves. The teacher will be there for those who
want him, the others he need not worry about. Marks are not
necessary. The only spur to industry should be the desire and
thirst for knowledge. Let us relegate such systems embodying
the threats of roll calls, and quizzes of high school calibre to the
discord in favor of a more mature plan whose only attraction is
knowledge.

The McGill Daily of Montreal
reveals in a recent issue the startling
information that the University's
founder and benefactor, James McGill owed his brewer fifteen

the legislature. The administrators
of the McGill estate later settled the
account for five pounds.

his boosters on mortgaged beer,
forces one to exclaim, "just like a
politician !"
The knowledge, however, that the
administrators settled a fifteen
pound bill for five pounds without
indicating what they had done with
the other ten gives birth to inferences that are too obvious and too
natural to warrant command in
connection with administerial practices.

member of the New York College
Club declares in a dispatch to the
same publication that the college
club has "an ill effect on new graduates. New York, it appears, is
particularly pregnant with such organizations and year after year
hordes of graduates descend on the

increase in enrollment in the College was not urgently desired. We
believe that this old policy is dead, that a new era has started in which
the undergraduate schools will not only recover their former prestige,
but will surpass it. Perhaps we have been too harsh in writing of the
past, perhaps we attach too much importance to the present, perhaps
we are too optimistic as regards the future. Nevertheless, it seems to
us that the investigation now being conducted represents a change of
policy that will prove of great benefit. The essential point is not that
the committee may recommend great changes, it is that an effort is
being made to improve the undergraduate colleges by facing facts.

•

The problems being discussed range all the way from additions
to the curriculum to what may be done for activities. Perhaps the most
important problem is whether the University now offers sufficient
courses to enable each student to acquire a liberal education, and if
the answer is no (as we confidently expect it to be) what courses should
be added. We can suggest quite a few: Political Economy courses, such
as Accounting and Money and Banking should be instituted for men

enrich the curriculum. That is to compel the high and mighty Business
Economics faculty to thiow open more of their courses to students in
other colleges and to abolish some of the pre-requisites in that school.

so we cannot do this subject justice. But when our digestion fails,
when some other misfortune occurs to make us slightly bitter, we shall
then take up the question of the "splendid isolation" of the Business
School more fully.

system we have at present, whereby each instructor has several students
under his wing is far from satisfactory. Many of the instructors regard

seniors each year. The advantages of this plan are two-fold. First, the

the curriculum and the peculiarities of each course and, secondly, hc

haphazard fashion. It would be advantageous to have him assisted by
seniors as they would be men who had just recently taken the courses

Assistant Dean any changes which the professors make in their courses

of reforming itself, the markers. Long have we undergraduates

established by individual instructors. Will the new marking system relieve this difficulty to any extent? Obviously not, for every
member of the faculty still will have different ideas as to who
among his students may be classed as an honor student. Some
cynical and hard-hearted members of the faculty believe none of

have been meaningless. A111 degrees of difference lie between these
two extremes and each student is compared with his fellows on a
different basis. The scholarship committee may think that numerical averages form a sound means for awarding honors, the Phi
Beta Kappa Society may award its key to men with the highest
average, but neither has a reliable source for its judgments.
Two men with equal ability who have done equal amounts of work
may under either the present or future system be classified in separate divisions as to their respective merits.
Again, I say, the faculty should adopt some agreement
among all its members so that a uniform system may result which
will take into account the varying difficulty of different subjects
and what may be reasonably expected from a conscientious student.
The trend indicated by the new marking system is the establishment of standards of scholarship among the undergraduates in
accord with those already existing in the graduate school. The
purpose of any marking system is to establish a basis on which
a student may judge the results of his own labor in comparison
with the rest of the student body. If his work is satisfactory it
will be so designated and if he is far better than average, he
will have the satisfaction of knowing this. But what good does
such a system accomplish? It will remove any attempts to judge
.and compare students by the actual percentage of given knowledge which they have learnt to appy-; but aside from this it is not
much of an improvement.
If the faculty is actually sincere in its desire to establish the
ideal system, then let there be no system at all. A complete abolition of any form of marking whatsoever is more highly desirable
than any possible system involving marks. A college student is supposedly a seeker of knowledge. The teacher is there to aid his students in acquiring this knowledge, and his should not be the duty
.of passing judgment. A man comes to college to equip himself for
life and only the future will tell whether he has been sucecssful.
The world in which he makes his living will be the real judge of
his accomplishments and ability. A true teacher is one whose superior knowledge equips him to become a source and radiating
.center of information. Coming to the teacher with a respect for
his knowledge and the desire to partake of it even as Aristotle
learnt from Plato, the student should be on a thoroughly friendly
basis with his teachers. As long as teachers are required to officially judge their pupils, no true feeling of friendship can arise
between the two. Once, however, the student knows that upon
himself alone rests the burden of accomplishment then will he regard his teachers in a purely unselfish light. There will be no need
to distinguish between handshaking and sincerity—the former
will have no purpose.
Of course, the plan will meet with objections. The average
college .student needs constant driving if he is to acquire knowledge. This plan however is not concerned with the average student, for Hopkins is endeavoring to avoid mediocrity. Raise entrance requirements and eliminate many of the undesirables who
,are wasting their time in college. Those who do get in and yet do
not work will cause no trouble, for the knowledge is there to be
absorbed by those who want it; while those who ignore it are
digging their own graves. The teacher will be there for those who
want him, the others he need not worry about. Marks are not
necessary. The only spur to industry should be the desire and
thirst for knowledge. Let us relegate such systems embodying
the threats of roll calls, and quizzes of high school calibre to the
discord in favor of a more mature plan whose only attraction is
knowledge.
